New Kantorovich type inequalities for negative parameters

Shigeru Furuichi and Hamid Reza Moradi
Abstract.

We show the following result: Let A,B∈𝔹​(ℋ)𝐴𝐵𝔹ℋA,B\in\mathbb{B}\left(\mathcal{H}\right) be two strictly positive operators such that A≤B𝐴𝐵A\leq B and m​𝟏ℋ≤B≤M​𝟏ℋ𝑚subscript1ℋ𝐵𝑀subscript1ℋm{{\mathbf{1}}_{\mathcal{H}}}\leq B\leq M{{\mathbf{1}}_{\mathcal{H}}} for some scalars 0<m<M0𝑚𝑀0<m<M. Then

Bp≤exp⁡(M​𝟏ℋ−BM−m​ln⁡mp+B−m​𝟏ℋM−m​ln⁡Mp)≤K​(m,M,p,q)​Aq for ​p≤0,−1≤q≤0formulae-sequencesuperscript𝐵𝑝𝑀subscript1ℋ𝐵𝑀𝑚superscript𝑚𝑝𝐵𝑚subscript1ℋ𝑀𝑚superscript𝑀𝑝𝐾𝑚𝑀𝑝𝑞superscript𝐴𝑞formulae-sequence for 𝑝01𝑞0{{B}^{p}}\leq\exp\left(\frac{M{{\mathbf{1}}_{\mathcal{H}}}-B}{M-m}\ln{{m}^{p}}+\frac{B-m{{\mathbf{1}}_{\mathcal{H}}}}{M-m}\ln{{M}^{p}}\right)\leq K\left(m,M,p,q\right){{A}^{q}}\quad\text{ for }p\leq 0,-1\leq q\leq 0

where K​(m,M,p,q)𝐾𝑚𝑀𝑝𝑞K\left(m,M,p,q\right) is the generalized Kantorovich constant with two parameters. In addition, we obtain Kantorovich type inequalities for the chaotic order.

Key words and phrases:
Kantorovich type inequality, chaotic order, order reversing operators, log-convex functions, Mond-Pečarić method

Primary 47A63, Secondary 46L05, 47A60.

1. Introduction and Preliminaries


In what follows, a capital letter means a bounded linear operator on a complex Hilbert space ℋℋ\mathcal{H}. An operator A𝐴A is said to be positive (denoted by A≥0𝐴0A\geq 0 ) if ⟨A​x,x⟩≥0𝐴𝑥𝑥0\left\langle Ax,x\right\rangle\geq 0 for all x∈ℋ,𝑥ℋx\in\mathcal{H}, and also an operator A𝐴A is said to be strictly positive (denoted by A>0𝐴0A>0) if A𝐴A is positive and invertible. Here 𝟏ℋsubscript1ℋ{{\mathbf{1}}_{\mathcal{H}}} stands for the identity operator on ℋℋ\mathcal{H}. S​p​(A)𝑆𝑝𝐴Sp\left(A\right) denotes the usual spectrum of A𝐴A. We take an interval I⊆ℝ𝐼ℝI\subseteq\mathbb{R}. If a positive function f:I→(0,∞):𝑓→𝐼0f:I\to\left(0,\infty\right) satisfies

(1.1) f​((1−v)​x+v​y)≤f1−v​(x)​fv​(y),𝑓1𝑣𝑥𝑣𝑦superscript𝑓1𝑣𝑥superscript𝑓𝑣𝑦f\left(\left(1-v\right)x+vy\right)\leq{{f^{1-v}\left(x\right)}}{{f^{v}\left(y\right)}},

for all x,y∈I𝑥𝑦𝐼x,y\in I and v∈[0,1]𝑣01v\in\left[0,1\right], then we say that f𝑓f is a logarithmically convex (or simply, log-convex) function on I𝐼I. The weighted arithmetic-geometric mean inequality readily yields that every log-convex function is also convex. It is worth emphasizing that the function f​(t)=tp𝑓𝑡superscript𝑡𝑝f\left(t\right)={{t}^{p}} is log-convex for p≤0𝑝0p\leq 0 on (0,∞)0\left(0,\infty\right).

The “Löwner-Heinz inequality” asserts that 0≤A≤B0𝐴𝐵0\leq A\leq B ensures Ap≤Bpsuperscript𝐴𝑝superscript𝐵𝑝{{A}^{p}}\leq{{B}^{p}} for any p∈[0,1]𝑝01p\in\left[0,1\right]. As is well-known, the Löwner-Heinz inequality does not always hold for p>1𝑝1p>1. The following theorem due to Furuta [8, Theorem 2.1] (see also [9, Theorem 4.1]) is the starting point for our discussion.

Theorem 1.1.

Let A,B∈𝔹​(ℋ)𝐴𝐵𝔹ℋA,B\in\mathbb{B}\left(\mathcal{H}\right) be two strictly positive operators such that A≤B𝐴𝐵A\leq B and m​𝟏ℋ≤A≤M​𝟏ℋ𝑚subscript1ℋ𝐴𝑀subscript1ℋm{{\mathbf{1}}_{\mathcal{H}}}\leq A\leq M{{\mathbf{1}}_{\mathcal{H}}} for some scalars 0<m<M0𝑚𝑀0<m<M. Then

Ap≤K​(m,M,p)​Bp≤(Mm)p−1​Bp for ​p≥1,formulae-sequencesuperscript𝐴𝑝𝐾𝑚𝑀𝑝superscript𝐵𝑝superscript𝑀𝑚𝑝1superscript𝐵𝑝 for 𝑝1{{A}^{p}}\leq{{K}}\left(m,M,p\right){{B}^{p}}\leq{{\left(\frac{M}{m}\right)}^{p-1}}{{B}^{p}}\quad\text{ for }p\geq 1,

where K​(m,M,p)𝐾𝑚𝑀𝑝K\left(m,M,p\right) is a generalized Kantorovich constant in the sense of Furuta [7]:

(1.2) K​(m,M,p)=(m​Mp−M​mp)(p−1)​(M−m)​(p−1p​Mp−mpm​Mp−M​mp)p for ​p∈ℝ.formulae-sequence𝐾𝑚𝑀𝑝𝑚superscript𝑀𝑝𝑀superscript𝑚𝑝𝑝1𝑀𝑚superscript𝑝1𝑝superscript𝑀𝑝superscript𝑚𝑝𝑚superscript𝑀𝑝𝑀superscript𝑚𝑝𝑝 for 𝑝ℝK\left(m,M,p\right)=\frac{(m{{M}^{p}}-M{{m}^{p}})}{\left(p-1\right)\left(M-m\right)}{{\left(\frac{p-1}{p}\frac{{{M}^{p}}-{{m}^{p}}}{m{{M}^{p}}-M{{m}^{p}}}\right)}^{p}}\quad\text{ for }p\in\mathbb{R}.

In [14, Theorem 2.1], Mićić, Pečarić and Seo proved some fascinating results about the function preserving the operator order, under a general setting:

Theorem 1.2.

Let A𝐴A and B𝐵B be two strictly positive operators on a Hilbert space ℋℋ\mathcal{H} satisfying m​𝟏ℋ≤A≤M​𝟏ℋ𝑚subscript1ℋ𝐴𝑀subscript1ℋm{{\mathbf{1}}_{\mathcal{H}}}\leq A\leq M{{\mathbf{1}}_{\mathcal{H}}} for some scalars 0<m<M0𝑚𝑀0<m<M. holds for

The following converse of Theorem 1.2 was proven in [16, Theorem 2.1]:

Theorem 1.3.

Let A𝐴A and B𝐵B be two strictly positive operators on a Hilbert space ℋℋ\mathcal{H} satisfying m​𝟏ℋ≤B≤M​𝟏ℋ𝑚subscript1ℋ𝐵𝑀subscript1ℋm{{\mathbf{1}}_{\mathcal{H}}}\leq B\leq M{{\mathbf{1}}_{\mathcal{H}}} for some scalars 0<m<M0𝑚𝑀0<m<M. Suppose that either of the following conditions holds: (i) g𝑔g is decreasing convex on I𝐼I, or (ii) g𝑔g is increasing concave on I𝐼I. If A≤B𝐴𝐵A\leq B, then for a given α>0𝛼0\alpha>0 in the case (i) or α<0𝛼0\alpha<0 in the case (ii)

(1.4) f​(B)≤α​g​(A)+β​𝟏ℋ,𝑓𝐵𝛼𝑔𝐴𝛽subscript1ℋf\left(B\right)\leq\alpha g\left(A\right)+\beta{{\mathbf{1}}_{\mathcal{H}}},

holds with β𝛽\beta as (1.3).

This paper is organized by four sections. The proof of our main result, Theorem 2.1, is given in Section 2. The essential idea is to consider the log-convex function instead of the convex function in Theorem 1.3. As applications, in Section 3, we show some characterizations of the chaotic order. Further results based on the Mond-Pečarić method are given in Section 4.

2. Functions reversing operator order


In the sequel, afsubscript𝑎𝑓{{a}_{f}} and bfsubscript𝑏𝑓{{b}_{f}} will refer to those of Theorem 1.2. Our principal result is the following theorem. The role of (1.1) is clearly brought out in our proof.

3. Applications to chaotic order


In this section, we show some inequalities on chaotic order (i.e., log⁡A≤log⁡B𝐴𝐵\log A\leq\log B for A,B>0𝐴𝐵0A,B>0). To achieve our next results, we need the following lemma. Its proof is standard but we provide a proof for the sake of completeness.

Lemma 3.1.

Let A,B∈𝔹​(ℋ)𝐴𝐵𝔹ℋA,B\in\mathbb{B}\left(\mathcal{H}\right) be two strictly positive operators. Then the following statements are equivalent:

  • (i)

    log⁡A≤log⁡B𝐴𝐵\log A\leq\log B.

  • (ii)

    Br≤(Br2​Ap​Br2)rp+rsuperscript𝐵𝑟superscriptsuperscript𝐵𝑟2superscript𝐴𝑝superscript𝐵𝑟2𝑟𝑝𝑟B^{r}\leq\left(B^{\frac{r}{2}}A^{p}B^{\frac{r}{2}}\right)^{\frac{r}{p+r}} for p≤0𝑝0p\leq 0 and r≤0𝑟0r\leq 0.

Proof.

From the well-known “chaotic Furuta inequality” (see, e.g., [2, 3, 6]) the order log⁡A≥log⁡B𝐴𝐵\log A\geq\log B is equivalent to the inequality (Br2​Ap​Br2)pp+r≥Brsuperscriptsuperscript𝐵𝑟2superscript𝐴𝑝superscript𝐵𝑟2𝑝𝑝𝑟superscript𝐵𝑟\left(B^{\frac{r}{2}}A^{p}B^{\frac{r}{2}}\right)^{\frac{p}{p+r}}\geq B^{r} for p,r≥0𝑝𝑟0p,r\geq 0 and A,B>0𝐴𝐵0A,B>0. The assertion (i) is equivalent to the order log⁡B−1≤log⁡A−1superscript𝐵1superscript𝐴1\log B^{-1}\leq\log A^{-1}. By the use of chaotic Furuta inequality, the order log⁡B−1≤log⁡A−1superscript𝐵1superscript𝐴1\log B^{-1}\leq\log A^{-1} is equivalent to the inequality

(3.1) B−r≤(B−r2​A−p​B−r2)rp+r for ​p,r≥0.formulae-sequencesuperscript𝐵𝑟superscriptsuperscript𝐵𝑟2superscript𝐴𝑝superscript𝐵𝑟2𝑟𝑝𝑟 for 𝑝𝑟0{{B}^{-r}}\leq{{\left({{B}^{\frac{-r}{2}}}{{A}^{-p}}{{B}^{\frac{-r}{2}}}\right)}^{\frac{r}{p+r}}}\quad\text{ for }p,r\geq 0.

This is equivalent to the inequality

Br′≤(Br′2​Ap′​Br′2)r′p′+r′ for ​p′,r′≤0,formulae-sequencesuperscript𝐵superscript𝑟′superscriptsuperscript𝐵superscript𝑟′2superscript𝐴superscript𝑝′superscript𝐵superscript𝑟′2superscript𝑟′superscript𝑝′superscript𝑟′ for superscript𝑝′superscript𝑟′0{{B}^{r^{\prime}}}\leq{{\left({{B}^{\frac{r^{\prime}}{2}}}{{A}^{p^{\prime}}}{{B}^{\frac{r^{\prime}}{2}}}\right)}^{\frac{r^{\prime}}{p^{\prime}+r^{\prime}}}}\quad\text{ for }p^{\prime},r^{\prime}\leq 0,

by substituting p′=−psuperscript𝑝′𝑝p^{\prime}=-p and r′=−rsuperscript𝑟′𝑟r^{\prime}=-r in (3.1). We thus obtain the desired conclusion. ∎

As an application of Corollary 2.2, we have the following result:

Corollary 3.1.

Let A,B∈𝔹​(ℋ)𝐴𝐵𝔹ℋA,B\in\mathbb{B}\left(\mathcal{H}\right) be two strictly positive operators such that m​𝟏ℋ≤B≤M​𝟏ℋ𝑚subscript1ℋ𝐵𝑀subscript1ℋm{{\mathbf{1}}_{\mathcal{H}}}\leq B\leq M{{\mathbf{1}}_{\mathcal{H}}} for some scalars 0<m<M0𝑚𝑀0<m<M and log⁡A≤log⁡B𝐴𝐵\log A\leq\log B. Then for p≤0𝑝0p\leq 0 and r≤−1𝑟1r\leq-1,

4. Miscellanea


By the similar way presented in the previous sections, it is also possible to improve the results which previously obtained by employing the Mond-Pečarić method.

As a multiple operator version of the celebrated “Davis-Choi-Jensen inequality” [1], Mond and Pečarić in [15, Theorem 1] proved the inequality

(4.1) f​(∑i=1nwi​Φi​(Ai))≤∑i=1nwi​Φi​(f​(Ai)),𝑓superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑤𝑖subscriptΦ𝑖subscript𝐴𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑤𝑖subscriptΦ𝑖𝑓subscript𝐴𝑖f\left(\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}{{{w}_{i}}{{\Phi}_{i}}\left({{A}_{i}}\right)}\right)\leq\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}{{{w}_{i}}{{\Phi}_{i}}\left(f\left({{A}_{i}}\right)\right)},

for operator convex function f𝑓f defined on an interval I𝐼I, where ΦisubscriptΦ𝑖{{\Phi}_{i}} (i=1,…,n𝑖1…𝑛i=1,\ldots,n) are normalized positive linear mappings from 𝔹​(ℋ)𝔹ℋ\mathbb{B}\left(\mathcal{H}\right) to 𝔹​(𝒦)𝔹𝒦\mathbb{B}\left(\mathcal{K}\right), A1,…,Ansubscript𝐴1…subscript𝐴𝑛{{A}_{1}},\ldots,{{A}_{n}} are self-adjoint operators with spectra in I𝐼I and w1,…,wnsubscript𝑤1…subscript𝑤𝑛{{w}_{1}},\ldots,{{w}_{n}} are non-negative real numbers with ∑i=1nwi=1superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑤𝑖1\sum\nolimits_{i=1}^{n}{{{w}_{i}}}=1.

In a reverse direction to that of inequality (4.1) we have the following:

Theorem 4.1.

Let ΦisubscriptΦ𝑖{{\Phi}_{i}} be normalized positive linear maps from 𝔹​(ℋ)𝔹ℋ\mathbb{B}\left(\mathcal{H}\right) to 𝔹​(𝒦)𝔹𝒦\mathbb{B}\left(\mathcal{K}\right), Ai∈𝔹​(ℋ)subscript𝐴𝑖𝔹ℋ{{A}_{i}}\in\mathbb{B}\left(\mathcal{H}\right) be self-adjoint operators with m​𝟏ℋ≤Ai≤M​𝟏ℋ𝑚subscript1ℋsubscript𝐴𝑖𝑀subscript1ℋm{{\mathbf{1}}_{\mathcal{H}}}\leq{{A}_{i}}\leq M{{\mathbf{1}}_{\mathcal{H}}} for some scalars m<M𝑚𝑀m<M and wisubscript𝑤𝑖{{w}_{i}} be positive numbers such that ∑i=1nwi=1superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑤𝑖1\sum\nolimits_{i=1}^{n}{{{w}_{i}}}=1. (4.2) ∑i=1nwi​Φi​(f​(Ai))superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑤𝑖subscriptΦ𝑖𝑓subscript𝐴𝑖\displaystyle\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}{{{w}_{i}}{{\Phi}_{i}}\left(f\left({{A}_{i}}\right)\right)} ≤∑i=1nwi​Φi​(exp⁡(M​𝟏ℋ−AiM−m​ln⁡f​(m)+Ai−m​𝟏ℋM−m​ln⁡f​(M)))absentsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑤𝑖subscriptΦ𝑖𝑀subscript1ℋsubscript𝐴𝑖𝑀𝑚𝑓𝑚subscript𝐴𝑖𝑚subscript1ℋ𝑀𝑚𝑓𝑀\displaystyle\leq\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}{{{w}_{i}}{{\Phi}_{i}}\left(\exp\left(\frac{M{{\mathbf{1}}_{\mathcal{H}}}-{{A}_{i}}}{M-m}\ln f\left(m\right)+\frac{{{A}_{i}}-m{{\mathbf{1}}_{\mathcal{H}}}}{M-m}\ln f\left(M\right)\right)\right)}
≤α​g​(∑i=1nwi​Φi​(Ai))+β​𝟏𝒦,absent𝛼𝑔superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑤𝑖subscriptΦ𝑖subscript𝐴𝑖𝛽subscript1𝒦\displaystyle\leq\alpha g\left(\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}{{{w}_{i}}{{\Phi}_{i}}\left({{A}_{i}}\right)}\right)+\beta{{\mathbf{1}}_{\mathcal{K}}},

holds with β𝛽\beta as in (1.3).

Proof.

Thanks to (2.2), we get

∑i=1nwi​Φi​(f​(Ai))superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑤𝑖subscriptΦ𝑖𝑓subscript𝐴𝑖\displaystyle\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}{{{w}_{i}}{{\Phi}_{i}}\left(f\left({{A}_{i}}\right)\right)} ≤∑i=1nwi​Φi​(exp⁡(M​𝟏ℋ−AiM−m​ln⁡f​(m)+Ai−m​𝟏ℋM−m​ln⁡f​(M)))absentsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑤𝑖subscriptΦ𝑖𝑀subscript1ℋsubscript𝐴𝑖𝑀𝑚𝑓𝑚subscript𝐴𝑖𝑚subscript1ℋ𝑀𝑚𝑓𝑀\displaystyle\leq\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}{{{w}_{i}}{{\Phi}_{i}}\left(\exp\left(\frac{M{{\mathbf{1}}_{\mathcal{H}}}-{{A}_{i}}}{M-m}\ln f\left(m\right)+\frac{{{A}_{i}}-m{{\mathbf{1}}_{\mathcal{H}}}}{M-m}\ln f\left(M\right)\right)\right)}

It is worth mentioning that, Theorem 4.1 is stronger than what appears in [13, Theorem 2.2].

Let I⊆ℝ𝐼ℝI\subseteq\mathbb{R} and f:I→ℝ:𝑓→𝐼ℝf:I\to\mathbb{R} be a continuous function and let A,B∈𝔹​(ℋ)𝐴𝐵𝔹ℋA,B\in\mathbb{B}\left(\mathcal{H}\right) be two strictly positive operators such that S​p​(A−12​B​A−12)⊆I𝑆𝑝superscript𝐴12𝐵superscript𝐴12𝐼Sp\left({{A}^{-\frac{1}{2}}}B{{A}^{-\frac{1}{2}}}\right)\subseteq I. Then the operator σfsubscript𝜎𝑓{{\sigma}_{f}} given by

A​σf​B=A12​f​(A−12​B​A−12)​A12,𝐴subscript𝜎𝑓𝐵superscript𝐴12𝑓superscript𝐴12𝐵superscript𝐴12superscript𝐴12A{{\sigma}_{f}}B={{A}^{\frac{1}{2}}}f\left({{A}^{-\frac{1}{2}}}B{{A}^{-\frac{1}{2}}}\right){{A}^{\frac{1}{2}}},

is called f𝑓f-connection (cf. [11]). We shall show the following result involving f𝑓f-connection of strictly positive operators.

Theorem 4.2.

Let ΦΦ\Phi be a normalized positive linear map from 𝔹​(ℋ)𝔹ℋ\mathbb{B}\left(\mathcal{H}\right) to 𝔹​(𝒦)𝔹𝒦\mathbb{B}\left(\mathcal{K}\right) and A,B∈𝔹​(ℋ)𝐴𝐵𝔹ℋA,B\in\mathbb{B}\left(\mathcal{H}\right) be two strictly positive operators such that m​A≤B≤M​A𝑚𝐴𝐵𝑀𝐴mA\leq B\leq MA for some scalars 0<m<M0𝑚𝑀0<m<M. If f𝑓f is a log-convex function on [m,M]𝑚𝑀\left[m,M\right], then for a given α∈ℝ𝛼ℝ\alpha\in\mathbb{R}

(4.3) Φ​(A​σf​B)Φ𝐴subscript𝜎𝑓𝐵\displaystyle\Phi\left(A{{\sigma}_{f}}B\right) ≤Φ​(A12​exp⁡(M​𝟏ℋ−A−12​B​A−12M−m​ln⁡f​(m)+A−12​B​A−12−m​𝟏ℋM−m​ln⁡f​(M))​A12)absentΦsuperscript𝐴12𝑀subscript1ℋsuperscript𝐴12𝐵superscript𝐴12𝑀𝑚𝑓𝑚superscript𝐴12𝐵superscript𝐴12𝑚subscript1ℋ𝑀𝑚𝑓𝑀superscript𝐴12\displaystyle\leq\Phi\left({{A}^{\frac{1}{2}}}\exp\left(\frac{M{{\mathbf{1}}_{\mathcal{H}}}-{{A}^{-\frac{1}{2}}}B{{A}^{-\frac{1}{2}}}}{M-m}\ln f\left(m\right)+\frac{{{A}^{-\frac{1}{2}}}B{{A}^{-\frac{1}{2}}}-m{{\mathbf{1}}_{\mathcal{H}}}}{M-m}\ln f\left(M\right)\right){{A}^{\frac{1}{2}}}\right)
≤β​Φ​(A)+α​(Φ​(A)​σf​Φ​(B)),absent𝛽Φ𝐴𝛼Φ𝐴subscript𝜎𝑓Φ𝐵\displaystyle\leq\beta\Phi\left(A\right)+\alpha\left(\Phi\left(A\right){{\sigma}_{f}}\Phi\left(B\right)\right),

holds with β𝛽\beta as in (1.3).

Proof.

We give a lengthy sketch but routine calculations. It follows from Theorem 4.1 that

(4.4) Ψ​(f​(A−12​B​A−12))Ψ𝑓superscript𝐴12𝐵superscript𝐴12\displaystyle\Psi\left(f\left({{A}^{-\frac{1}{2}}}B{{A}^{-\frac{1}{2}}}\right)\right) ≤Ψ​(exp⁡(M​𝟏ℋ−A−12​B​A−12M−m​ln⁡f​(m)+A−12​B​A−12−m​𝟏ℋM−m​ln⁡f​(M)))absentΨ𝑀subscript1ℋsuperscript𝐴12𝐵superscript𝐴12𝑀𝑚𝑓𝑚superscript𝐴12𝐵superscript𝐴12𝑚subscript1ℋ𝑀𝑚𝑓𝑀\displaystyle\leq\Psi\left(\exp\left(\frac{M{{\mathbf{1}}_{\mathcal{H}}}-{{A}^{-\frac{1}{2}}}B{{A}^{-\frac{1}{2}}}}{M-m}\ln f\left(m\right)+\frac{{{A}^{-\frac{1}{2}}}B{{A}^{-\frac{1}{2}}}-m{{\mathbf{1}}_{\mathcal{H}}}}{M-m}\ln f\left(M\right)\right)\right)
≤β​𝟏𝒦+α​f​(Ψ​(A−12​B​A−12)),absent𝛽subscript1𝒦𝛼𝑓Ψsuperscript𝐴12𝐵superscript𝐴12\displaystyle\leq\beta{{\mathbf{1}}_{\mathcal{K}}}+\alpha f\left(\Psi\left({{A}^{-\frac{1}{2}}}B{{A}^{-\frac{1}{2}}}\right)\right),

where ΨΨ\Psi is a normalized positive linear map from 𝔹​(ℋ)𝔹ℋ\mathbb{B}\left(\mathcal{H}\right) to 𝔹​(𝒦)𝔹𝒦\mathbb{B}\left(\mathcal{K}\right).

By taking Ψ​(X):=Φ​(A)−12​Φ​(A12​X​A12)​Φ​(A)−12assignΨ𝑋Φsuperscript𝐴12Φsuperscript𝐴12𝑋superscript𝐴12Φsuperscript𝐴12\Psi\left(X\right):=\Phi{{\left(A\right)}^{-\frac{1}{2}}}\Phi\left({{A}^{\frac{1}{2}}}X{{A}^{\frac{1}{2}}}\right)\Phi{{\left(A\right)}^{-\frac{1}{2}}}, where ΦΦ\Phi is an arbitrary normalized positive linear map in (4.4), we obtain the desired result (4.3). ∎

In the sequel, we use the notation A​♮v​B=A12​(A−12​B​A−12)v​A12𝐴subscript♮𝑣𝐵superscript𝐴12superscriptsuperscript𝐴12𝐵superscript𝐴12𝑣superscript𝐴12A{{\natural}_{v}}B={{A}^{\frac{1}{2}}}{{\left({{A}^{-\frac{1}{2}}}B{{A}^{-\frac{1}{2}}}\right)}^{v}}{{A}^{\frac{1}{2}}}, (v∈ℝ)𝑣ℝ\left(v\in\mathbb{R}\right). The following corollary follows by setting f​(t)=tp𝑓𝑡superscript𝑡𝑝f\left(t\right)={{t}^{p}} (p≤0)𝑝0\left(p\leq 0\right) in the previous theorem.

Corollary 4.1.

Let ΦΦ\Phi be a normalized positive linear map from 𝔹​(ℋ)𝔹ℋ\mathbb{B}\left(\mathcal{H}\right) to 𝔹​(𝒦)𝔹𝒦\mathbb{B}\left(\mathcal{K}\right) and A,B∈𝔹​(ℋ)𝐴𝐵𝔹ℋA,B\in\mathbb{B}\left(\mathcal{H}\right) be two strictly positive operators such that m​A≤B≤M​A𝑚𝐴𝐵𝑀𝐴mA\leq B\leq MA for some scalars 0<m<M0𝑚𝑀0<m<M. Then for a given α∈ℝ𝛼ℝ\alpha\in\mathbb{R},

Φ​(A​♮p​B)Φ𝐴subscript♮𝑝𝐵\displaystyle\Phi\left(A{{\natural}_{p}}B\right) ≤Φ​(A12​exp⁡(M​𝟏ℋ−A−12​B​A−12M−m​ln⁡mp+A−12​B​A−12−m​𝟏ℋM−m​ln⁡Mp)​A12)absentΦsuperscript𝐴12𝑀subscript1ℋsuperscript𝐴12𝐵superscript𝐴12𝑀𝑚superscript𝑚𝑝superscript𝐴12𝐵superscript𝐴12𝑚subscript1ℋ𝑀𝑚superscript𝑀𝑝superscript𝐴12\displaystyle\leq\Phi\left({{A}^{\frac{1}{2}}}\exp\left(\frac{M{{\mathbf{1}}_{\mathcal{H}}}-{{A}^{-\frac{1}{2}}}B{{A}^{-\frac{1}{2}}}}{M-m}\ln{{m}^{p}}+\frac{{{A}^{-\frac{1}{2}}}B{{A}^{-\frac{1}{2}}}-m{{\mathbf{1}}_{\mathcal{H}}}}{M-m}\ln{{M}^{p}}\right){{A}^{\frac{1}{2}}}\right)
≤β​Φ​(A)+α​(Φ​(A)​♮p​Φ​(B)),absent𝛽Φ𝐴𝛼Φ𝐴subscript♮𝑝Φ𝐵\displaystyle\leq\beta\Phi\left(A\right)+\alpha\left(\Phi\left(A\right){{\natural}_{p}}\Phi\left(B\right)\right),

holds for p≤0𝑝0p\leq 0, where β𝛽\beta is defined by (2.5).

Fujii and Seo [4, Theorem 2.2] showed the following operator inequality: Let A,B∈𝔹​(ℋ)𝐴𝐵𝔹ℋA,B\in\mathbb{B}\left(\mathcal{H}\right) be two positive operators and ΦΦ\Phi be a normalized positive linear map, then

(4.5) Φ​(A)​♮p​Φ​(B)≤Φ​(A​♮p​B) for ​p∈[−1,0).formulae-sequenceΦ𝐴subscript♮𝑝Φ𝐵Φ𝐴subscript♮𝑝𝐵 for 𝑝10\Phi\left(A\right){{\natural}_{p}}\Phi\left(B\right)\leq\Phi\left(A{{\natural}_{p}}B\right)\quad\text{ for }p\in\left[-1,0\right).

The following corollary is a complementary result for (4.5). The proof is immediate by using Corollary 4.1.

Corollary 4.2.

Let ΦΦ\Phi be a normalized positive linear map from 𝔹​(ℋ)𝔹ℋ\mathbb{B}\left(\mathcal{H}\right) to 𝔹​(𝒦)𝔹𝒦\mathbb{B}\left(\mathcal{K}\right) and A,B∈𝔹​(ℋ)𝐴𝐵𝔹ℋA,B\in\mathbb{B}\left(\mathcal{H}\right) be two strictly positive operators such that m​A≤B≤M​A𝑚𝐴𝐵𝑀𝐴mA\leq B\leq MA for some scalars 0<m<M0𝑚𝑀0<m<M and p≤0𝑝0p\leq 0.

  • (i)

    As a ratio type reverse of inequality (4.5) we have:

    Φ​(A​♮p​B)Φ𝐴subscript♮𝑝𝐵\displaystyle\Phi\left(A{{\natural}_{p}}B\right) ≤Φ​(A12​exp⁡(M​𝟏ℋ−A−12​B​A−12M−m​ln⁡mp+A−12​B​A−12−m​𝟏ℋM−m​ln⁡Mp)​A12)absentΦsuperscript𝐴12𝑀subscript1ℋsuperscript𝐴12𝐵superscript𝐴12𝑀𝑚superscript𝑚𝑝superscript𝐴12𝐵superscript𝐴12𝑚subscript1ℋ𝑀𝑚superscript𝑀𝑝superscript𝐴12\displaystyle\leq\Phi\left({{A}^{\frac{1}{2}}}\exp\left(\frac{M{{\mathbf{1}}_{\mathcal{H}}}-{{A}^{-\frac{1}{2}}}B{{A}^{-\frac{1}{2}}}}{M-m}\ln{{m}^{p}}+\frac{{{A}^{-\frac{1}{2}}}B{{A}^{-\frac{1}{2}}}-m{{\mathbf{1}}_{\mathcal{H}}}}{M-m}\ln{{M}^{p}}\right){{A}^{\frac{1}{2}}}\right)
    ≤K​(m,M,p)​(Φ​(A)​♮p​Φ​(B)),absent𝐾𝑚𝑀𝑝Φ𝐴subscript♮𝑝Φ𝐵\displaystyle\leq K\left(m,M,p\right)\left(\Phi\left(A\right){{\natural}_{p}}\Phi\left(B\right)\right),

    where K​(m,M,p)𝐾𝑚𝑀𝑝K\left(m,M,p\right) is defined by (1.2).

  • (ii)

    As a difference type reverse of inequality (4.5) we have:

    Φ​(A​♮p​B)Φ𝐴subscript♮𝑝𝐵\displaystyle\Phi\left(A{{\natural}_{p}}B\right) ≤Φ​(A12​exp⁡(M​𝟏ℋ−A−12​B​A−12M−m​ln⁡mp+A−12​B​A−12−m​𝟏ℋM−m​ln⁡Mp)​A12)absentΦsuperscript𝐴12𝑀subscript1ℋsuperscript𝐴12𝐵superscript𝐴12𝑀𝑚superscript𝑚𝑝superscript𝐴12𝐵superscript𝐴12𝑚subscript1ℋ𝑀𝑚superscript𝑀𝑝superscript𝐴12\displaystyle\leq\Phi\left({{A}^{\frac{1}{2}}}\exp\left(\frac{M{{\mathbf{1}}_{\mathcal{H}}}-{{A}^{-\frac{1}{2}}}B{{A}^{-\frac{1}{2}}}}{M-m}\ln{{m}^{p}}+\frac{{{A}^{-\frac{1}{2}}}B{{A}^{-\frac{1}{2}}}-m{{\mathbf{1}}_{\mathcal{H}}}}{M-m}\ln{{M}^{p}}\right){{A}^{\frac{1}{2}}}\right)
    ≤C​(m,M,p)​Φ​(A)+Φ​(A)​♮p​Φ​(B),absent𝐶𝑚𝑀𝑝Φ𝐴Φ𝐴subscript♮𝑝Φ𝐵\displaystyle\leq C\left(m,M,p\right)\Phi\left(A\right)+\Phi\left(A\right){{\natural}_{p}}\Phi\left(B\right),

    where C​(m,M,p)𝐶𝑚𝑀𝑝C\left(m,M,p\right) is defined by (3.2).

We close this paper by presenting a result on the inequalities for the Tsallis relative operator entropy. The Tsallis relative operator entropy with negative parameter was introduced in [5] as

(4.6) Tp​(A|B)=A​♮p​B−Ap for ​p<0.formulae-sequencesubscript𝑇𝑝conditional𝐴𝐵𝐴subscript♮𝑝𝐵𝐴𝑝 for 𝑝0{{T}_{p}}\left(A|B\right)=\frac{A{{\natural}_{p}}B-A}{p}\quad\text{ for }p<0.

Research in this field includes obtaining new inequalities and refining existing ones. For example, in [4, Theorem 3.1 (2′superscript2′2^{\prime})], the following inequality has been already shown:

(4.7) Φ​(Tp​(A|B))≤Tp​(Φ​(A)|Φ​(B)) for ​p∈[−1,0).formulae-sequenceΦsubscript𝑇𝑝conditional𝐴𝐵subscript𝑇𝑝conditionalΦ𝐴Φ𝐵 for 𝑝10\Phi\left({{T}_{p}}\left(A|B\right)\right)\leq{{T}_{p}}\left(\Phi\left(A\right)|\Phi\left(B\right)\right)\quad\text{ for }p\in\left[-1,0\right).

We shall give complementary inequalities to the inequality (4.7), thanks to Corollary 4.2.

Theorem 4.3.

Let ΦΦ\Phi be normalized positive linear map from 𝔹​(ℋ)𝔹ℋ\mathbb{B}\left(\mathcal{H}\right) to 𝔹​(𝒦)𝔹𝒦\mathbb{B}\left(\mathcal{K}\right) and A,B∈𝔹​(ℋ)𝐴𝐵𝔹ℋA,B\in\mathbb{B}\left(\mathcal{H}\right) be two strictly positive operators such that m​A≤B≤M​A𝑚𝐴𝐵𝑀𝐴mA\leq B\leq MA for some scalars 0<m<M0𝑚𝑀0<m<M. Then for p∈[−1,0)𝑝10p\in\left[-1,0\right),

(4.8) Φ​(Tp​(A|B))Φsubscript𝑇𝑝conditional𝐴𝐵\displaystyle\Phi\left({{T}_{p}}\left(A|B\right)\right)
≥1p​Φ​(A12​exp⁡(M​𝟏ℋ−A−12​B​A−12M−m​ln⁡mp+A−12​B​A−12−m​𝟏ℋM−m​ln⁡Mp)​A12−A)absent1𝑝Φsuperscript𝐴12𝑀subscript1ℋsuperscript𝐴12𝐵superscript𝐴12𝑀𝑚superscript𝑚𝑝superscript𝐴12𝐵superscript𝐴12𝑚subscript1ℋ𝑀𝑚superscript𝑀𝑝superscript𝐴12𝐴\displaystyle\quad\geq\frac{1}{p}\Phi\left({{A}^{\frac{1}{2}}}\exp\left(\frac{M{{\mathbf{1}}_{\mathcal{H}}}-{{A}^{-\frac{1}{2}}}B{{A}^{-\frac{1}{2}}}}{M-m}\ln{{m}^{p}}+\frac{{{A}^{-\frac{1}{2}}}B{{A}^{-\frac{1}{2}}}-m{{\mathbf{1}}_{\mathcal{H}}}}{M-m}\ln{{M}^{p}}\right){{A}^{\frac{1}{2}}}-A\right)
≥Tp​(Φ​(A)|Φ​(B))−(1−K​(m,M,p)p)​(Φ​(A)​♮p​Φ​(B)),absentsubscript𝑇𝑝conditionalΦ𝐴Φ𝐵1𝐾𝑚𝑀𝑝𝑝Φ𝐴subscript♮𝑝Φ𝐵\displaystyle\quad\geq{{T}_{p}}\left(\Phi\left(A\right)|\Phi\left(B\right)\right)-\left(\frac{1-K\left(m,M,p\right)}{p}\right)\left(\Phi\left(A\right){{\natural}_{p}}\Phi\left(B\right)\right),

where K​(m,M,p)𝐾𝑚𝑀𝑝K\left(m,M,p\right) is defined by (1.2) and

(4.9) Φ​(Tp​(A|B))Φsubscript𝑇𝑝conditional𝐴𝐵\displaystyle\Phi\left({{T}_{p}}\left(A|B\right)\right)
≥1p​Φ​(A12​exp⁡(M​𝟏ℋ−A−12​B​A−12M−m​ln⁡mp+A−12​B​A−12−m​𝟏ℋM−m​ln⁡Mp)​A12−A)absent1𝑝Φsuperscript𝐴12𝑀subscript1ℋsuperscript𝐴12𝐵superscript𝐴12𝑀𝑚superscript𝑚𝑝superscript𝐴12𝐵superscript𝐴12𝑚subscript1ℋ𝑀𝑚superscript𝑀𝑝superscript𝐴12𝐴\displaystyle\quad\geq\frac{1}{p}\Phi\left({{A}^{\frac{1}{2}}}\exp\left(\frac{M{{\mathbf{1}}_{\mathcal{H}}}-{{A}^{-\frac{1}{2}}}B{{A}^{-\frac{1}{2}}}}{M-m}\ln{{m}^{p}}+\frac{{{A}^{-\frac{1}{2}}}B{{A}^{-\frac{1}{2}}}-m{{\mathbf{1}}_{\mathcal{H}}}}{M-m}\ln{{M}^{p}}\right){{A}^{\frac{1}{2}}}-A\right)
≥Tp​(Φ​(A)|Φ​(B))+C​(m,M,p)p​Φ​(A),absentsubscript𝑇𝑝conditionalΦ𝐴Φ𝐵𝐶𝑚𝑀𝑝𝑝Φ𝐴\displaystyle\quad\geq{{T}_{p}}\left(\Phi\left(A\right)|\Phi\left(B\right)\right)+\frac{C\left(m,M,p\right)}{p}\Phi\left(A\right),

where C​(m,M,p)𝐶𝑚𝑀𝑝C\left(m,M,p\right) is defined by (3.2).

Proof.

It follows from Corollary 4.2 (i) that

(4.10) Φ​(A​♮p​B−Ap)Φ𝐴subscript♮𝑝𝐵𝐴𝑝\displaystyle\Phi\left(\frac{A{{\natural}_{p}}B-A}{p}\right)
≥1p​Φ​(A12​exp⁡(M​𝟏ℋ−A−12​B​A−12M−m​ln⁡mp+A−12​B​A−12−m​𝟏ℋM−m​ln⁡Mp)​A12−A)absent1𝑝Φsuperscript𝐴12𝑀subscript1ℋsuperscript𝐴12𝐵superscript𝐴12𝑀𝑚superscript𝑚𝑝superscript𝐴12𝐵superscript𝐴12𝑚subscript1ℋ𝑀𝑚superscript𝑀𝑝superscript𝐴12𝐴\displaystyle\quad\geq\frac{1}{p}\Phi\left({{A}^{\frac{1}{2}}}\exp\left(\frac{M{{\mathbf{1}}_{\mathcal{H}}}-{{A}^{-\frac{1}{2}}}B{{A}^{-\frac{1}{2}}}}{M-m}\ln{{m}^{p}}+\frac{{{A}^{-\frac{1}{2}}}B{{A}^{-\frac{1}{2}}}-m{{\mathbf{1}}_{\mathcal{H}}}}{M-m}\ln{{M}^{p}}\right){{A}^{\frac{1}{2}}}-A\right)
≥K​(m,M,p)​(Φ​(A)​♮p​Φ​(B))−Φ​(A)p.absent𝐾𝑚𝑀𝑝Φ𝐴subscript♮𝑝Φ𝐵Φ𝐴𝑝\displaystyle\quad\geq\frac{K\left(m,M,p\right)\left(\Phi\left(A\right){{\natural}_{p}}\Phi\left(B\right)\right)-\Phi\left(A\right)}{p}.

On account of (4.6) the inequalities in (4.10) are equivalent to (4.8). From Corollary 4.2 (ii) we have

Φ​(A​♮p​B−Ap)Φ𝐴subscript♮𝑝𝐵𝐴𝑝\displaystyle\Phi\left(\frac{A{{\natural}_{p}}B-A}{p}\right)
≥1p​Φ​(A12​exp⁡(M​𝟏ℋ−A−12​B​A−12M−m​ln⁡mp+A−12​B​A−12−m​𝟏ℋM−m​ln⁡Mp)​A12−A)absent1𝑝Φsuperscript𝐴12𝑀subscript1ℋsuperscript𝐴12𝐵superscript𝐴12𝑀𝑚superscript𝑚𝑝superscript𝐴12𝐵superscript𝐴12𝑚subscript1ℋ𝑀𝑚superscript𝑀𝑝superscript𝐴12𝐴\displaystyle\quad\geq\frac{1}{p}\Phi\left({{A}^{\frac{1}{2}}}\exp\left(\frac{M{{\mathbf{1}}_{\mathcal{H}}}-{{A}^{-\frac{1}{2}}}B{{A}^{-\frac{1}{2}}}}{M-m}\ln{{m}^{p}}+\frac{{{A}^{-\frac{1}{2}}}B{{A}^{-\frac{1}{2}}}-m{{\mathbf{1}}_{\mathcal{H}}}}{M-m}\ln{{M}^{p}}\right){{A}^{\frac{1}{2}}}-A\right)
≥C​(m,M,p)​Φ​(A)+Φ​(A)​♮p​Φ​(B)−Φ​(A)p,absent𝐶𝑚𝑀𝑝Φ𝐴Φ𝐴subscript♮𝑝Φ𝐵Φ𝐴𝑝\displaystyle\quad\geq\frac{C\left(m,M,p\right)\Phi\left(A\right)+\Phi\left(A\right){{\natural}_{p}}\Phi\left(B\right)-\Phi\left(A\right)}{p},

which is equivalent to (4.9). ∎
